image.altText: Gemma Houghton holds a footy while leaning on a railing in the stands looking away

props.synopsis: Two-time All Australian Gemma Houghton says her passion for football ran dry after her mate's death, as a study has found female athletes face more psychosocial stressors including exposure to sexual harassment and challenges around parenting.

title.children: AFLW star says losing her best friend to suicide left her struggling on field

image.altText: The SA flag flies above South Australia's Parliament House.

props.synopsis: A SA government minister's adviser appeared to receive "large sums of money" into a bank account, prompting an investigation into potential bribery, the state's outgoing anti-corruption commissioner reveals in a report tabled in parliament.

title.children: Unnamed ministerial adviser investigated over 'large sums of money' in bank account, SA ICAC says

image.altText: Close up of small furry animal

props.synopsis: Poison-laced food used to kill rabbits is being distributed in a region where work is underway to restore the population of an endangered species equally susceptible to the bait.

title.children: Poison-laced carrots 'a risk' to endangered bandicoots in Adelaide Hills

image.altText: About a dozen student are seen talking in a courtyard, in front of a tall sandstone clock tower at the University of Melbourne.

props.synopsis: The federal government's plan to cap international student numbers has split the tertiary education sector, drawing uproar from prestigious urban universities but cautious optimism from their regional and suburban competitors.

title.children: International student cap draws fury from top universities

image.altText: Unidentified male adult walks hand in hand with child

props.synopsis: South Australian parents could soon be able to apply for information about serious child sex offenders in their area. Here's how it would work.

title.children: South Australia is moving to create a public child sex offender register. How would it work?

image.altText: Thanasi

props.synopsis: Thanasi Kokkinakis sends Stefanos Tsitsipas packing at the US Open, as a score of fellow Australians make their way through to the second round.

title.children: Standing ovation for Kokkinakis after US Open upset on bumper day for Australian tennis stars

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: The US and UK elections this year are proving to be significant flex points, and that has consequences for us in Australia. But it also shows how clear values are the only workable response to chaos.

title.children: Australia is labouring through wrenching transitions, and there's only one way out of the chaos

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and wearing glasses looking at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: What was meant to be a dream holiday in Japan for Cassandra Nichterlein and her young family turned into a costly nightmare when their return flight from Japan was cancelled.

title.children: A family was left $7,000 out of pocket after a flight cancellation. Jetstar initially offered them $600

image.altText: A sparkling sky with blue and purple tones. A brown sign says River Murray International Dark Sky Reserve

props.synopsis: A year-long legal stoush between the WA Tourism Commission and a small South Australian council over an attempt to trademark the term "Dark Sky Festival" has come to an end.

title.children: Who owns the Dark Sky? Country council wins trademark battle against Tourism WA

image.altText: A woman holds her child with a demolished home in the background

props.synopsis: As many as 700,000 people are expected to attended an outdoor mass with Pope Francis next month in Dili, so authorities are bulldozing the homes of about 200 of the city's poorest residents to make room.

title.children: 'They've destroyed our homes': Ana Bela's house was bulldozed to make way for a mass with the pope

image.altText: Stack of several thousand dollars worth of Australian $50 notes showing David Unaipon

props.synopsis: New analysis released by the super industry has found one in four workers is missing out on compulsory superannuation payments, with women and those in lower-paid jobs worst hit.

title.children: 'Leaves people poorer when they retire': Could you be missing out on super payments?

image.altText: a zoomed in woolworths sign

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is expected to open lower despite Wall Street ending higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Annual rate of inflation falls to 3.5 per cent in July, down from 3.8 per cent in June

image.altText: Protesters shouting and speaking into megaphone at a CFMEU rally in Sydney's CBD

props.synopsis: Tens of thousands of tradies across the country have marched in protest against the federal government's decision to put the construction arm of the CFMEU under administration.

title.children: PM warns of 'consequences' as thousands of CFMEU workers march across Australia

image.altText: A man with grey hair and beard leans over bushfire bunker built into ground

props.synopsis: An Adelaide Hills father installed a six-person bushfire bunker at his property after the 2019 Cudlee Creek bushfire, without first seeking planning approvals — now, the council have issued a removal notice — a decision which he is appealing.

title.children: Daniel Katz installed a 'last resort' bunker after fleeing a bushfire, but he's been told to remove it

image.altText: Charlot Salwai stands at a podium holding a piece of paper and speaking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Vanuatu's prime minister and a senior regional diplomat warn Australia and New Zealand not to use a high-profile new policing initiative to box out strategic competitors from the region.

title.children: Vanuatu and Melanesia say 'cryptic' Pacific Policing Initiative should not lock China out of region

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding several pages of a household power bill in their hands

props.synopsis: Australia's peak energy user group and one of its biggest retailers sound the alarm on complex power prices, saying they're not working and may be harming.

title.children: Consumers are ‘punished’ by cost-reflective power prices, yet they do little of what they’re supposed to do

image.altText: A man named Clifford Sunfly stands in front of a Toyota four-wheel drive.

props.synopsis: Ravaged by drug abuse, rampant unemployment and deep social dysfunction, Balgo is one of Australia's most remote communities. But there are opportunities on the horizon, as a community with ancient traditions looks to a modern future.

title.children: In Balgo, getting people into work is the battle. But locals are working hard to drive change

image.altText: Trump christians pic

props.synopsis: A revised indictment is filed against former US president Donald Trump in the case involving alleged interference of the 2020 US election.

title.children: Donald Trump faces revised US indictment in election subversion case

image.altText: Catherine King

props.synopsis: Federal Infrastructure Minister Catherine King faces a worsening revolt from the nation's most populous states over plans to slash the Commonwealth's share of funding for national road and railway projects.

title.children: NSW and Victoria challenge federal government's 50:50 road and rail funding deal

image.altText: Boeing starliner

props.synopsis: With NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore stranded aboard the ISS for months, a decorated former astronaut tells the ABC they would know and have trained for the risks but the view is definitely worth it.

title.children: NASA's astronauts now aboard the ISS face 'untold consequences' for their future

image.altText: A soldier and a civilian man having a conversation

props.synopsis: The IDF says it rescued Arab Bedouin citizen of Israel Qaid Farhan Alkadi, 52, "in a complex operation in the southern Gaza Strip".

title.children: Israel rescues 52-year-old hostage taken in October 7 terror attack

image.altText: High view of detention centre

props.synopsis: Queensland's Inspector of Detention Services has investigated youth detention in the state and made 15 recommendations to address human rights concerns.

title.children: Inspector finds children locked in rooms with no toilet or running water at Queensland youth detention centre

image.altText: Michael Voss holds his phone up as two people scramble out of a Mercedes Benz crashed sideways in a residential street.

props.synopsis: Michael Voss conducted a citizen's arrest when he pinned a 16-year-old to the ground and waited for police. What is a citizen's arrest and would you do it?

title.children: What are the risks of a citizen's arrest like the one AFL coach Michael Voss made?

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: Rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve and other central banks will create a near-irresistible pressure for Australia's Reserve Bank to follow, potentially very soon.

title.children: Interest rate cuts in the US should mean cuts in Australia too — perhaps quickly

image.altText: A photo showing a man wearing glasses and wearing a black baseball cap, ookingdirectly at the camera

props.synopsis: The NT's new CLP government has promised to curb soaring crime with tougher laws and enforcement. But the manager of an Alice Springs shopping centre has found pulling back on security, instead of increasing it, has worked better.

title.children: The new NT government plans to toughen crime laws, but this shopping centre is suggesting an alternative

image.altText: Chappell Roan performs onstage during Lollapalooza at Grant Park on August 01, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois.

props.synopsis: With pop superstar Chappell Roan speaking out repeatedly against "creepy" behaviour from fans, we unpack what celebrities do and don't owe their audiences.

title.children: Chappell Roan wants fans to back off. Do celebrities owe us anything?

image.altText: Angie Ballard in racing wheelchair faces down wearing helmet and glasses, on a racing track.

props.synopsis: As she heads into an incredible seventh Paralympic Games, wheelchair racing champion Angie Ballard reflects on her journey to get here and her feelings about leading the Australian team into Paris.

title.children: From panic attacks to sponsorship woes, Paralympic champion Angie Ballard has overcome challenges for her seventh Games

image.altText: A fallen tree over house

props.synopsis: More inclement weather is expected on Wednesday as a cold front makes its way across western Victoria.

title.children: Victorians told to brace for damaging winds as strong cold front moves across state

image.altText: Matthew Owies

props.synopsis: Goalsneak Matthew Owies will miss Carlton's elimination final against the Brisbane Lions after the AFL upheld his one-match ban for a dangerous tackle.

title.children: Blues forward Owies to miss finals clash over dangerous tackle, despite winning a free kick for it

image.altText: Volodymyr Zelenskyy speaks into a microphone with one arm raised, in front of a blue background.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has defended Kyiv's surprise incursion into Russia's Kursk region after Russian officials decried the move as "playing with fire".

title.children: Zelenskyy defends surprise Kursk incursion after Russian official decries 'playing with fire'

image.altText: A weathered hand holding a blue sparkly boulder opal.

props.synopsis: Opal miners are concerned about the future of their industry as the Queensland government buys a former cattle property used for mining. With 50 per cent of the region's opals coming from this one property, it's raising alarm bells.

title.children: Is the golden age of outback opal hunters coming to an end?

image.altText: CCTV shows a man in a cap and button up running away.

props.synopsis: The baby boy was with his family in a park at Stones Corner when an unknown man allegedly approached them and poured boiling coffee over the infant.

title.children: Police seeking man after boiling coffee was thrown at baby in Brisbane park

image.altText: A blurred photo of a dog.

props.synopsis: Despite Instagram's policies against explicit content, the ABC has uncovered dozens of accounts on the platform — each with hundreds of followers — sharing images and videos of dogs being sexually exploited as well as other types of animal cruelty.

title.children: Instagram awash with easily accessible, 'horrific' accounts depicting animal abuse

props.synopsis: Australia won a record number of gold medals in Paris. This comes after the government poured more than $400 million dollars into high-performance sport.

title.children: WATCH: What's the price of an Olympic gold medal?
